[[Spain]] | capacity = 3,865 | chairman = {{flagicon|Spain}} [[Enrique Cerezo]] | manager = {{flagicon|Serbia}} [[Milinko PantiÄ]] | league = [[Segunda DivisiÃ³n B|2ÂªB - Group 1]] | season = 2010â11 | position = [[Segunda DivisiÃ³n B|2ÂªB - Group 1]], '''11th''' | pattern_la1 = _am1011h | pattern_b1 = _AM1011H | pattern_ra1 = _am1011h | pattern_sh1 = _white stripes | pattern_so1 = _redtop | leftarm1 = ffffff | body1 = ffffff | rightarm1 = ffffff | shorts1 = 0000FF | socks1 = 0000FF | pattern_la2 = _am1011a | pattern_b2 = _AM1011A | pattern_ra2 = _am1011a | pattern_sh2 = _white stripes | pattern_so2 = _redtop | leftarm2 = ffffff | body2 = ffffff | rightarm2 = ffffff | shorts2 = 000055 | socks2 = 000055 | current = 2011â12 Segunda DivisiÃ³n B }} '''AtlÃ©tico Madrid B''' is a [[List of football clubs in Spain|Spanish football team]] based in [[Madrid]], in the [[Community of Madrid|namesake community]]. Founded in 1963, it is the [[reserve team]] of [[AtlÃ©tico Madrid]], and currently plays in ''[[Segunda DivisiÃ³n B]]'', holding home games at ''Nuevo Cerro del Espino''. ==History== The club was founded in 1963 as ''Reyfra AtlÃ©tico Club''. In 1970, it absorbed ''Aviaco MadrileÃ±o CF'', which was established in 1967 when ''MadrileÃ±o CF'' (1956â67) and ''AD Aviaco'' [[Mergers and acquisitions|merged]], became affiliated with AtlÃ©tico Madrid and changed its name to ''AtlÃ©tico MadrileÃ±o Club de FÃºtbol''. In 1991, the name changed to ''AtlÃ©tico Madrid B''. Having already played from 1980â86 in ''[[Segunda DivisiÃ³n]]'', the reserves fluctuated between that level and ''[[Segunda DivisiÃ³n B]]'' - created in 1977 as the new third division - in the following decades. In the [[1998â99 Segunda DivisiÃ³n|1998â99 season]], the team, which featured [[RubÃ©n Baraja]], future [[Valencia CF]] and [[Spain national football team|Spain]] star in central [[Midfielder|midfield]], finished in second position in division two, but was ineligible to [[La Liga]] promotion. The entire 2000's were spent in the third level, but several players continued to make the transition to the first team, including the likes of [[David de Gea]], [[Ãlvaro DomÃ­nguez Soto|Ãlvaro DomÃ­nguez]], [[Antonio LÃ³pez Guerrero|Antonio LÃ³pez]], [[Gabriel FernÃ¡ndez Arenas|Gabi]], [[Mario SuÃ¡rez Mata|Mario SuÃ¡rez]], [[Koke (footballer born 1992)|Koke]], [[Ignacio Camacho]] and [[Fernando Torres]]. B|Second Division B]]''': 1988â89, 2000â01, 2003â04 ==Stadium== ''Nuevo Cerro del Espino'' is located in the city of [[Madrid]]'s sports facilities, in [[Majadahonda]]. It also serves as an habitual training ground for the main squad, and as the home ground of local [[CF Rayo Majadahonda]] ([[Tercera DivisiÃ³n|fourth division]]). Besides, this facility hosts simposiums on rules of the National Professional Soccer League on stadia security. *'''Technical details''': **Dimensions: 106x70 meters **Surface: Natural grass **Capacity: 3,376 spectators **Opening year: 1995 **Services: Newsroom, radio booths and cafeteria of the club.
